questions.stem: A school psychologist is evaluating a 7-year-old bilingual child whose parents recently immigrated from Guatemala. The child has limited English proficiency and attended school sporadically in her home country. Which assessment approach is MOST appropriate for estimating this child's cognitive processing abilities while minimizing the influence of language and acquired knowledge?

options.text: Administer the WISC-V with a Spanish-speaking interpreter translating all verbal subtests
Administer the KABC-II using the Luria model and report the Mental Processing Index
Administer the SB5 and interpret only the Nonverbal IQ
Administer the KABC-II using the CHC model and report the Fluid-Crystallized Index

questions.explanation: The KABC-II's Luria model is specifically recommended for linguistically and culturally diverse examinees because the Mental Processing Index (MPI) deliberately excludes the Knowledge/Gc scale, preventing acquired verbal knowledge from depressing the global cognitive score. The CHC model includes crystallized ability, which would disadvantage this child. Using an interpreter violates standardized administration procedures and compromises validity. While the SB5 Nonverbal IQ is useful, the KABC-II Luria model was explicitly designed for this purpose and provides a more theoretically grounded approach.

questions.stem: A neuropsychologist evaluates a 10-year-old with documented ADHD whose WISC-V Full Scale IQ is 94. However, the child's VCI (112) and FRI (108) are substantially higher than the WMI (78) and PSI (76). Which supplementary index score would BEST represent this child's overall reasoning ability without the confound of attentional and processing speed deficits?

options.text: Cognitive Proficiency Index (CPI)
Quantitative Reasoning Index (QRI)
General Ability Index (GAI)
Nonverbal Index (NVI)

questions.explanation: The General Ability Index (GAI) is computed from VCI and FRI (or VSI) subtests only, excluding Working Memory and Processing Speed indices. For children with ADHD, processing speed and working memory deficits can significantly depress the FSIQ below the level of actual reasoning ability. The GAI provides a purer estimate of general cognitive ability in such cases. The CPI combines WMI and PSI, which are the child's weaknesses. The QRI and NVI do not serve this purpose.

questions.stem: In a forensic evaluation related to Atkins v. Virginia, a defendant was tested with the WAIS-III (normed in 1997) and obtained an FSIQ of 73. The evaluator recommends retesting with the WAIS-IV (normed in 2008). Based on the Flynn effect, which outcome is MOST likely?

options.text: The WAIS-IV FSIQ will be approximately 76 due to updated norms providing a broader standardization sample
The WAIS-IV FSIQ will be approximately 70 because the more recent norms adjust for population-level IQ gains
The WAIS-IV FSIQ will remain at 73 because the Flynn effect only affects group-level statistics, not individual scores
The WAIS-IV FSIQ will be approximately 67 because the Flynn effect inflates scores by approximately 5 points per decade

questions.explanation: The Flynn effect describes population-level IQ gains of approximately 3 points per decade. When a new edition of a test is normed, the normative sample performs better than previous samples, resulting in slightly lower individual scores on the new edition. With approximately 11 years between the WAIS-III (1997) and WAIS-IV (2008) norms, the expected score drop is approximately 3 points, yielding an estimated FSIQ of 70. This is forensically significant in Atkins cases because it can determine whether a defendant falls above or below the intellectual disability threshold.

questions.stem: Carroll's three-stratum theory organizes cognitive abilities hierarchically. Which of the following correctly describes the relationship among the three strata?

options.text: Stratum I contains broad abilities like Gf and Gc, Stratum II contains narrow abilities, and Stratum III represents g
Stratum I contains approximately 70 narrow abilities, Stratum II contains broad abilities like Gf and Gc, and Stratum III represents g
Stratum I represents g, Stratum II contains broad abilities, and Stratum III contains narrow abilities measured by individual subtests
Stratum I contains seven primary mental abilities identified by Thurstone, Stratum II contains Gf and Gc, and Stratum III represents g

questions.explanation: Carroll's (1993) three-stratum theory, derived from meta-analysis of factor-analytic studies, organizes cognitive abilities with Stratum III (g, general intelligence) at the apex, Stratum II containing broad abilities (Gf, Gc, Gv, Ga, Gs, Gsm, Glr, Grw), and Stratum I containing approximately 70 narrow abilities measured by individual subtests. This hierarchy was integrated with Cattell-Horn's Gf-Gc theory to form the modern CHC framework used in WJ-IV and KABC-II construction.

questions.stem: A clinician needs to assess the cognitive abilities of a 12-year-old child who is deaf from birth and communicates exclusively through ASL. Which instrument is the MOST appropriate choice?

options.text: Raven's Standard Progressive Matrices
WISC-V Performance subtests only
Leiter International Performance Scale, Third Edition (Leiter-3)
Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test, Fifth Edition (PPVT-5)

questions.explanation: The Leiter-3 is the most appropriate instrument because it requires no spoken language for either administration or response. Instructions are given entirely through pantomime and gestures, and responses are nonverbal (pointing or manipulative). While Raven's uses nonverbal content, its standard administration still involves verbal instructions. The WISC-V verbal subtests would be inappropriate, and even performance subtests typically require verbal instructions. The PPVT-5 requires the examiner to speak words aloud, making it inappropriate for a deaf child.

questions.stem: Select ALL criteria required for a diagnosis of intellectual disability according to the DSM-5.

options.text: Deficits in intellectual functioning confirmed by clinical assessment and individualized standardized intelligence testing (approximately IQ 70 or below)
Deficits in adaptive functioning that result in failure to meet developmental and sociocultural standards for personal independence and social responsibility
Onset of intellectual and adaptive deficits during the developmental period
IQ score at least 2 standard deviations below the mean on the Wechsler scales specifically
Severity classification based on the level of support needed across conceptual, social, and practical adaptive domains

questions.explanation: The DSM-5 requires three criteria for intellectual disability: (1) deficits in intellectual functioning confirmed by standardized testing (approximately IQ 70 or below, accounting for measurement error), (2) deficits in adaptive functioning across conceptual, social, and practical domains, and (3) onset during the developmental period. Severity (Mild, Moderate, Severe, Profound) is determined by adaptive functioning level, not IQ cutoffs alone. The DSM-5 does not specify Wechsler scales; any standardized individually administered intelligence test is acceptable.

questions.stem: Select ALL statements that are TRUE regarding the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scales, Fifth Edition (SB5) compared to Wechsler scales.

options.text: The SB5 measures each of its five cognitive factors through both verbal and nonverbal routes
The SB5 uses a routing procedure to establish appropriate starting points rather than age-based starting points
The SB5 composite scores use a standard deviation of 16, while Wechsler uses 15
The SB5 has an extended IQ range of 40-160, making it more useful at the extremes of the distribution
The SB5 covers a broader age range (2-85+) than any single Wechsler scale

questions.explanation: The SB5 measures five factors (Fluid Reasoning, Knowledge, Quantitative Reasoning, Visual-Spatial Processing, Working Memory) each through both verbal and nonverbal routes (5x2 matrix of 10 subtests). It uses a routing procedure with two routing subtests to determine starting points. Its extended IQ range (40-160) is broader than Wechsler's, and it covers ages 2-85+. However, the statement about SD=16 is a common misconception tested on the EPPP: the SB5 FSIQ actually uses M=100, SD=15, the same as Wechsler. Earlier editions of the SB used SD=16, but the SB5 adopted SD=15.

questions.stem: Select ALL broad abilities that are included in the Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) theory at Stratum II.

options.text: Fluid Reasoning (Gf)
Crystallized Intelligence (Gc)
Processing Speed (Gs)
Emotional Intelligence (Ge)
Long-Term Retrieval (Glr)
Practical Intelligence (Gp)

questions.explanation: CHC theory at Stratum II includes broad abilities: Gf (Fluid Reasoning), Gc (Crystallized Intelligence), Gv (Visual Processing), Ga (Auditory Processing), Gs (Processing Speed), Gsm (Short-Term Memory), Glr (Long-Term Retrieval), and Grw (Reading/Writing). Emotional Intelligence (Ge) and Practical Intelligence (Gp) are not part of the CHC framework. Emotional intelligence is associated with Salovey and Mayer, while practical intelligence is part of Sternberg's triarchic theory.

questions.stem: Select ALL instruments that are co-normed with companion achievement batteries, allowing direct ability-achievement comparisons from the same normative sample.

options.text: WJ-IV Tests of Cognitive Abilities with WJ-IV Tests of Achievement
WAIS-IV with WIAT-4
KABC-II with KTEA-3
SB5 with WJ-IV Tests of Achievement
Raven's Progressive Matrices with WIAT-4

questions.explanation: Co-norming means both the cognitive and achievement batteries were standardized on the same normative sample, enabling direct statistical comparison. The WJ-IV cognitive and achievement batteries share a normative sample. The WAIS-IV/WISC-V are co-normed with the WIAT-4. The KABC-II is co-normed with the KTEA-3. The SB5 is not co-normed with the WJ-IV achievement battery, and Raven's is not co-normed with any achievement measure.

questions.stem: Select ALL characteristics of the Pattern of Strengths and Weaknesses (PSW) model for identifying specific learning disabilities.

options.text: It examines concordance between a specific cognitive processing weakness and a specific academic deficit
It requires evidence of discordance between overall cognitive ability and the specific area of academic weakness
It uses a multi-tiered system of interventions before conducting comprehensive testing
It relies on CHC theory to identify specific cognitive processes underlying academic skills
It requires documentation that cognitive strengths exist in areas unrelated to the academic deficit

questions.explanation: The PSW/concordance-discordance model examines: (1) concordance between specific cognitive weaknesses and specific academic deficits (e.g., weak phonological processing with weak reading decoding), (2) discordance between overall ability and the specific academic weakness, (3) presence of cognitive strengths in areas unrelated to the deficit (ruling out global intellectual deficiency), and (4) reliance on CHC theory to map cognitive processes to academic skills. The multi-tiered intervention approach describes RTI, not PSW.

questions.stem: For each Wechsler scale feature, select the CORRECT value.

rows.text: T-score at which Wechsler IQ = 2 SD below the mean

questions.explanation: Wechsler IQ and index scores use M=100, SD=15. Subtest scaled scores use M=10, SD=3. An IQ score 2 SD below the mean equals 100 - 2(15) = 70, which is the threshold for intellectual disability consideration. These metric distinctions are among the most frequently tested psychometric facts on the EPPP.

questions.stem: Match each intelligence theory to the theorist who proposed it.
questions.explanation: Spearman (1904) proposed the g factor using factor analysis. Thurstone (1938) identified seven primary mental abilities, challenging the single-g model. Gardner (1983) proposed eight multiple intelligences (linguistic, logical-mathematical, spatial, bodily-kinesthetic, musical, interpersonal, intrapersonal, naturalistic). Sternberg (1985) proposed the triarchic theory with analytical, creative, and practical components. Cattell (1963) distinguished fluid (Gf) from crystallized (Gc) intelligence, later expanded by Horn.

questions.stem: For each WAIS-IV index, select ALL subtests that are core components of that index.
questions.explanation: WAIS-IV core subtests by index: VCI = Similarities, Vocabulary, Information (Information not listed as an option here); PRI = Block Design, Matrix Reasoning, Visual Puzzles; WMI = Digit Span, Arithmetic; PSI = Symbol Search, Coding. Note: Information is also a VCI core subtest but was not among the options. Each index combines subtests measuring related cognitive abilities aligned with CHC theory.

questions.stem: For each SLD identification model, select ALL characteristics that apply.

columns.text: Endorsed by IDEA 2004 as alternative to discrepancy

questions.explanation: The Ability-Achievement Discrepancy model requires cognitive testing to establish an IQ-achievement gap and is criticized for the 'wait to fail' problem. RTI uses multi-tiered interventions and was endorsed by IDEA 2004 as an alternative to the discrepancy model. The PSW model requires comprehensive cognitive testing, identifies specific cognitive processing deficits, and is grounded in CHC theory to map cognitive weaknesses to academic skill deficits.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about score metrics in cognitive assessment.
All Wechsler IQ and index scores use a mean of [BLANK1] and a standard deviation of [BLANK2]. Subtest scaled scores across all Wechsler tests use a mean of [BLANK3] and a standard deviation of [BLANK4]. A Wechsler IQ score at the 2nd percentile corresponds to approximately [BLANK5], which is the threshold commonly considered in intellectual disability evaluation.
questions.explanation: Wechsler composite scores (FSIQ, index scores) use M=100, SD=15. Subtest scaled scores use M=10, SD=3. The 2nd percentile on the normal curve corresponds to approximately 2 SD below the mean: 100 - 2(15) = 70. This IQ 70 threshold, combined with adaptive behavior deficits, is used in intellectual disability evaluation. The SB5 adopted M=100, SD=15 for its current edition as well.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about the Cattell-Horn Gf-Gc theory and aging.
Raymond Cattell distinguished between two broad cognitive abilities. [BLANK1] intelligence refers to the capacity for novel reasoning and problem-solving independent of acquired knowledge, and it [BLANK2] with aging, particularly after age 60-70. [BLANK3] intelligence refers to accumulated knowledge and skills acquired through education and experience, and it [BLANK4] throughout the lifespan. This differential aging pattern produces what is known as the '[BLANK5]' on the Wechsler scales.
questions.explanation: Cattell's Gf-Gc theory distinguishes fluid intelligence (novel reasoning, peaks in early adulthood, declines with age) from crystallized intelligence (accumulated knowledge, stable or increasing through adulthood). On Wechsler scales, this produces the classic aging pattern: VCI (reflecting Gc) is relatively preserved while PSI (reflecting Gs, which also declines) shows the earliest and most pronounced age-related decline. This pattern is one of the most well-established findings in cognitive aging research.

questions.stem: A psychologist evaluates a 35-year-old patient who obtains a WAIS-IV profile showing VCI = 112, PRI = 98, WMI = 82, PSI = 79, and FSIQ = 92.
questions.explanation: A VCI-PSI discrepancy of 33 points with depressed WMI is clinically significant and suggests impaired processing efficiency relative to intact verbal reasoning. This pattern is commonly seen in TBI (affecting speed and memory), ADHD (affecting processing efficiency), and depression (psychomotor retardation). It does not suggest intellectual disability given the Average-to-High-Average VCI. Computing the GAI provides a reasoning estimate without processing speed confounds, and neuropsychological evaluation clarifies the etiology.

options.text: Traumatic brain injury affecting processing speed and working memory
ADHD with deficits in processing efficiency
Intellectual disability requiring adaptive behavior assessment
Depression affecting psychomotor speed and concentration
Compute the GAI to estimate reasoning ability without processing speed/working memory confounds
Conduct further neuropsychological evaluation to clarify the pattern of deficits
Retest with the SB5 to obtain a more accurate FSIQ
Review clinical history for head injury, ADHD symptoms, or depressive episodes

questions.centerStatement: 33-point discrepancy between VCI (112) and PSI (79), with WMI (82) also significantly below VCI

questions.stem: A school psychologist conducts an SLD evaluation for an 8-year-old with reading difficulties. The WJ-IV cognitive battery reveals GIA = 105, Gc = 108, Gf = 102, but Ga (Auditory Processing) = 74. The WJ-IV achievement battery shows Basic Reading Skills = 76 and Broad Math = 98.
questions.explanation: This profile exemplifies the PSW model: concordance between Ga weakness and reading deficit, discordance between overall ability (GIA 105) and reading (76), and preserved cognitive strengths (Gc, Gf, math). It also meets traditional discrepancy criteria (29-point GIA-reading gap). CHC theory links Ga (auditory processing, including phonological awareness) to basic reading skills. Additional assessment should rule out inadequate instruction, confirm the phonological processing deficit, and review intervention response per IDEA requirements.

options.text: SLD identification using the PSW/concordance-discordance model
SLD identification using the ability-achievement discrepancy model
A diagnosis of intellectual disability given the Ga score of 74
The theoretical link between phonological processing deficits and reading disability in CHC theory
Rule out inadequate instruction as the primary cause of reading difficulties
Assess phonological awareness and rapid naming to confirm the specific processing deficit
Administer the KABC-II to obtain a second global IQ score
Review response to evidence-based reading intervention (RTI data)

questions.centerStatement: Specific cognitive weakness in Auditory Processing (Ga = 74) concordant with weak Basic Reading Skills (76), with intact overall ability (GIA = 105) and intact math (98)

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are CORRECT about the assessment of culturally and linguistically diverse populations.
questions.passage: When assessing individuals from diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds, clinicians must consider several important principles. (1) Nonverbal tests such as Raven's Progressive Matrices are considered culture-free because they eliminate all cultural influences from the testing situation. (2) The KABC-II Luria model is recommended for culturally diverse examinees because it excludes the Knowledge/Gc scale from the global score. (3) The Leiter-3 uses pantomime and gestural instructions, making it appropriate for examinees who cannot understand spoken language. (4) Using an interpreter to translate verbal subtests of the WISC-V is an acceptable accommodation that maintains the test's standardized administration. (5) The term 'culture-reduced' is preferred over 'culture-free' because no test can completely eliminate all cultural influences on performance. (6) Even nonverbal tests can be influenced by culturally determined factors such as test-taking familiarity, motivation, and comfort with abstract reasoning tasks.
correctHighlights: (2) The KABC-II Luria model is recommended for culturally diverse examinees because it excludes the Knowledge/Gc scale from the global score.
(3) The Leiter-3 uses pantomime and gestural instructions, making it appropriate for examinees who cannot understand spoken language.
(5) The term 'culture-reduced' is preferred over 'culture-free' because no test can completely eliminate all cultural influences on performance.
(6) Even nonverbal tests can be influenced by culturally determined factors such as test-taking familiarity, motivation, and comfort with abstract reasoning tasks.
questions.explanation: Statements 2, 3, 5, and 6 are correct. Statement 1 is incorrect because no test is truly culture-free; Raven's is culture-reduced but still influenced by cultural factors. Statement 4 is incorrect because using an interpreter compromises standardized administration and validity. The correct principles emphasize that culture-reduced (not culture-free) assessment, appropriate instrument selection (KABC-II Luria, Leiter-3), and awareness that all tests retain some cultural influence are essential for ethical practice.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe the PHQ-9 as a measurement-based care instrument.
questions.passage: The Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) is widely used in measurement-based care. (1) The PHQ-9 contains 9 items, each corresponding to one of the nine DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder. (2) Items are rated from 0 (not at all) to 4 (extremely) over the past month. (3) Total scores range from 0 to 27, with a score of 10 or greater having 88% sensitivity and 88% specificity for detecting MDD. (4) The PHQ-9 is a proprietary instrument requiring a licensing fee, which limits its widespread use. (5) Severity cutoffs are: 0-4 minimal, 5-9 mild, 10-14 moderate, 15-19 moderately severe, 20-27 severe. (6) The PHQ-9 can be used for both screening and monitoring treatment response across sessions.
correctHighlights: (1) The PHQ-9 contains 9 items, each corresponding to one of the nine DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder.
(3) Total scores range from 0 to 27, with a score of 10 or greater having 88% sensitivity and 88% specificity for detecting MDD.
(5) Severity cutoffs are: 0-4 minimal, 5-9 mild, 10-14 moderate, 15-19 moderately severe, 20-27 severe.
(6) The PHQ-9 can be used for both screening and monitoring treatment response across sessions.
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, 5, and 6 are correct. Statement 2 is incorrect: items are rated from 0 (not at all) to 3 (nearly every day) over the past two weeks, not 0-4 over the past month. Statement 4 is incorrect: the PHQ-9 is freely available with no copyright cost, which is a major reason for its widespread adoption. The PHQ-9's dual utility for screening and progress monitoring makes it ideal for measurement-based care.

questions.stem: Place the Wechsler IQ classification labels in order from HIGHEST to LOWEST IQ range.
questions.explanation: The Wechsler classification system from highest to lowest: Very Superior (130+), Superior (120-129), High Average (110-119), Average (90-109), Low Average (80-89), Borderline (70-79), Extremely Low (69 and below, formerly called 'Intellectual Disability range'). Each category spans approximately one standard deviation (15 points), with Average covering the middle 50% of the population.

questions.stem: Arrange the three tiers of the Response to Intervention (RTI) model in order from LEAST intensive to MOST intensive.

items.text: Tier 3: Intensive individualized intervention; failure to respond may lead to special education referral
Tier 1: Universal evidence-based instruction for all students with screening to identify at-risk students
Tier 2: Targeted small-group interventions for students not making adequate progress, with progress monitoring

questions.explanation: The RTI model uses a three-tiered system of increasing intensity: Tier 1 provides high-quality, evidence-based instruction to all students in the general education classroom with universal screening. Students not making adequate progress move to Tier 2, which provides targeted small-group interventions with progress monitoring. Students who do not respond to Tier 2 move to Tier 3, which provides intensive, individualized intervention. Failure to respond at Tier 3 may result in referral for comprehensive evaluation for special education eligibility.

questions.stem: Based on the Cattell-Horn Gf-Gc theory, which graph BEST represents the typical trajectory of fluid intelligence (Gf) and crystallized intelligence (Gc) across the adult lifespan?

options.text: Both Gf and Gc increase steadily from age 20 to 80
Gf peaks in early adulthood then declines, while Gc remains stable or increases through middle adulthood before gradual late-life decline
Both Gf and Gc peak in middle adulthood (age 45-50) then decline at equal rates
Gc declines steadily from age 30 while Gf remains stable through old age

questions.explanation: The differential aging pattern of Gf and Gc is one of the most well-established findings in cognitive psychology. Fluid intelligence (Gf) peaks in early adulthood (around age 20-25) and then shows a gradual but continuous decline. Crystallized intelligence (Gc) continues to increase through middle adulthood as knowledge accumulates, remaining stable or showing only modest decline in later life. This produces the 'classic aging pattern' on Wechsler scales where VCI (Gc) is preserved while PSI (Gs, which tracks Gf decline) drops.

questions.stem: A therapist uses measurement-based care with the PHQ-9 administered at each session. Which pattern of PHQ-9 scores BEST indicates clinically significant change according to Jacobson and Truax's criteria?

options.text: Scores drop from 22 to 18 over 8 sessions (4-point decrease within the clinical range)
Scores drop from 20 to 5 over 12 sessions, crossing the clinical cutoff of 10 with a change exceeding the RCI
Scores fluctuate between 15 and 19 over 10 sessions with no consistent trend
Scores drop from 12 to 8 over 6 sessions, remaining in the mild range throughout

questions.explanation: Clinically significant change (Jacobson & Truax, 1991) requires two conditions: (1) the patient must cross from the clinical to the non-clinical distribution (post-treatment scores below the clinical cutoff), AND (2) the magnitude of change must exceed the Reliable Change Index (RCI), ensuring the change is not due to measurement error. A drop from 20 to 5 crosses the PHQ-9 clinical cutoff of 10 and represents a 15-point change (well exceeding the RCI). Option A shows change within the clinical range; option C shows no consistent change; option D shows movement within the subclinical range.

questions.stem: Categorize each CHC broad ability according to whether it typically DECLINES with aging or REMAINS STABLE/INCREASES through middle adulthood.

categories.label: Stable or Increases through Middle Adulthood

questions.explanation: In the CHC framework, abilities tied to biological processing efficiency tend to decline with age: Gf (novel reasoning), Gs (processing speed, showing the earliest and most pronounced decline), Gsm (short-term memory), and Glr (long-term retrieval efficiency). In contrast, abilities tied to accumulated knowledge and education tend to remain stable or increase: Gc (crystallized intelligence/verbal knowledge) and Grw (reading and writing skills). This differential pattern underlies the 'classic aging pattern' observed on comprehensive cognitive batteries.

questions.stem: Categorize each outcome monitoring instrument according to what it primarily measures.
questions.explanation: PHQ-9 measures depression severity (9 items mapping to DSM-5 MDD criteria). GAD-7 measures generalized anxiety severity (also sensitive to panic, social anxiety, PTSD). PCL-5 measures PTSD symptoms (20 items across 4 DSM-5 PTSD clusters). OQ-45 is a general psychotherapy outcome measure (3 subscales: Symptom Distress, Interpersonal Relations, Social Role). AUDIT screens for hazardous alcohol use (WHO-developed, 10 items). C-SSRS assesses suicidal ideation and behavior, which is grouped with depression instruments in clinical practice. Note: The C-SSRS is technically a suicide risk measure rather than a depression measure, but in this context it is most closely associated with depression assessment in measurement-based care.
